name: Gengar

abilities.name: Curse
abilities.text: Once during your turn (before your attack), you may move 1 damage counter from 1 of your opponent's Pokémon to another (even if it would Knock Out the other Pokémon). This power can't be used if Gengar is Asleep, Confused, or Paralyzed.

attacks.name: Dark Mind
attacks.text: If your opponent has any Benched Pokémon, choose 1 of them and this attack does 10 damage to it. (Don't apply Weakness and Resistance for Benched Pokémon.)

flavorText: Under a full moon, this Pokémon likes to mimic the shadows of people and laugh at their fright.

strengths: Curse can finish off damaged Pokemon without attacking
Dark Mind spreads damage, setting up Curse knockouts
weaknesses: Stage 2 requires full evolution line setup
80 HP is moderate for a Stage 2
Dark Mind's 30 damage is relatively low
Curse requires opponent's Pokemon to have damage
synergies: Mr. Mime (Invisible Wall blocks while Gengar sets up)
counters: Pokemon with high HP that don't get damaged easily
Gust of Wind to target Gastly/Haunter early

competitiveHistory: Gengar was a cornerstone of spread damage strategies in the classic era. The combination of Dark Mind's bench sniping and Curse's ability to move damage counters for knockouts created a unique control playstyle. When paired with Fossil Haunter's Transparency power, the Gastly evolution line became a formidable archetype. Gengar decks required skill to pilot but rewarded careful damage management with efficient multi-knockouts.

rulings.ruling: Curse can move a damage counter to a Pokemon that would be Knocked Out by it. The Knocked Out Pokemon is removed as normal.
You must move the damage counter from one of your opponent's Pokemon to another of your opponent's Pokemon - you cannot move it to your own.
Dark Mind's bench damage does not apply Weakness or Resistance.
If your opponent has no Benched Pokemon, Dark Mind still does 30 damage to the Active Pokemon but no bench damage occurs.
Multiple Gengars can each use Curse once per turn.
